summary: This is an FBI FD-302 interview report of a Federal Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant, conducted on August 14, 2019. The interview details the standard operating procedures for prisoner counts and rounds at the Metropolitan Correctional Facility (MCC) in New York, where Jeffrey Epstein was held. The lieutenant describes her duties and the process, but states she has no specific knowledge of any lapses in procedure related to Epstein's death and did not speak with the guards directly involved.

persons.context: A BOP Lieutenant interviewed by the FBI and OIG regarding standard prison procedures at the MCC. She described the count and rounds process and stated she had no knowledge of procedures not being followed related to Epstein's death.

events.title: FBI/OIG Interview of BOP Lieutenant
events.description: Federal investigators interviewed a Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant regarding standard operating procedures for prisoner counts and rounds at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The interview is conducted in the context of the investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein while in custody at the MCC.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Facility (MCC), New York, New York
keyFacts: A BOP Lieutenant with over 24 years of experience at the MCC was interviewed about prison procedures following Jeffrey Epstein's death.

The lieutenant described a detailed, two-person verification process for official prisoner counts, which involves physical checks, recording numbers, and verbal confirmation with an internal control center.
Guards are also required to conduct visual welfare "rounds" every 30-40 minutes to verify prisoners are alive and in their cells.
The lieutenant stated she had no knowledge of counts or rounds not being conducted and that no one would inform her if such lapses occurred.
She explicitly stated she did not speak with guards Thomas and Noel about the events surrounding Epstein's death on the night/morning in question.
